title: Ukyio-e: WC21
transcript:
Narrator: Curator Janice Katz.

Janice Katz: In this room are a set of 24 paintings by the artist Utagawa Toyokuni and it shows women
from a variety of walks of life, all the way from a woman from the Imperial Family to women who were part
of a wealthy samurai or merchant household and prostitutes, courtesans, all the way down to your most
humble prostitute who plied her trade in a boat. It's interesting that the 24 paintings seem to be divided
into two sets of 12. The first set of 12 are women who are a member of a noble family, women of wealthy
households, women who had various trades, such as saleswomen or women who worked on a farm. And
the other 12 are various courtesans and prostitutes of the different districts. Some of the licensed
pleasure quarters, but others of the other pleasure districts around Tokyo, such as Shinagawa and
Fukagawa.

Narrator: Curator Mami Hatayama.

Mami Hatayama: People had to follow social norms for their fashion and hairstyle. So they-- depending
on their age or work or social status, marital status, they had to wear differently. From their hairstyle and
fashion, we could identify what kind of work or social statuses they were.

Janice Katz: At this time of the Edo period, there was a real fascination with classifying everything,
showing the multitude varieties that you could have of a particular subject, whether it was a variety of
flowers that were available or a variety of beautiful women. It was a way of trying to understand in an
encyclopedic way everything about a particular subject. And there's actually a Japanese word for it. It's
called Taguchi [ph?], which means to exhaust. Basically, exhaust the varieties of a subject to learn
everything there is to know about it.
